questions.question: Under ASC 718, compensation cost for employee stock options is measured at:
questions.explanation: ASC 718 requires that compensation cost for employee stock options be measured at the grant date based on the fair value of the award. The grant date is when the employer and employee have a mutual understanding of the key terms and conditions.
questions.tip: Grant date = measurement date for employee awards.

questions.question: Compensation expense for stock options granted to employees is recognized over:

options.B: The requisite service period (typically the vesting period)
options.C: The period from grant date to exercise date
options.D: The fiscal year of the grant

questions.explanation: Compensation expense is recognized over the requisite service period, which is typically the vesting period. This matches the expense to the periods in which the employee provides service to earn the award.
questions.tip: Service period = vesting period for most stock options.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a common method for estimating the fair value of stock options?
questions.explanation: The intrinsic value method is not a fair value method—it measures the difference between the stock price and exercise price. ASC 718 requires fair value measurement using models like Black-Scholes, lattice models, or Monte Carlo simulations.
questions.tip: Intrinsic value ≠ fair value. Fair value uses option pricing models.

questions.question: On January 1, Year 1, ABC Corp granted 10,000 stock options to employees with a fair value of $8 per option. The options vest ratably over 4 years. What is the compensation expense for Year 1?
questions.explanation: Total compensation = 10,000 options × $8 = $80,000. With ratable vesting over 4 years, Year 1 expense = $80,000 ÷ 4 = $20,000.
questions.tip: Total fair value ÷ vesting period = annual expense (straight-line).

questions.question: Under current GAAP, how should a company account for stock option forfeitures?

options.A: Estimate forfeitures at grant date and adjust each period
options.B: Recognize forfeitures only when they occur
options.C: Either estimate forfeitures or recognize when they occur (accounting policy election)
options.D: Ignore forfeitures in compensation expense calculation

questions.explanation: ASC 718 allows companies to make an accounting policy election to either estimate forfeitures at the grant date or recognize forfeitures as they occur. This election must be applied consistently.
questions.tip: Forfeitures: estimate OR actual—it's an accounting policy choice.

questions.question: When recording compensation expense for stock options, the credit is recorded to:
questions.explanation: The journal entry to record stock option compensation expense is: Debit Compensation Expense, Credit Additional Paid-in Capital—Stock Options (or APIC—Stock Options). This reflects the equity nature of the award.
questions.tip: Stock option expense: Dr. Compensation Expense, Cr. APIC—Stock Options.

questions.question: An employee exercises 1,000 stock options with an exercise price of $25 per share. The options had a grant-date fair value of $10 per option (already expensed). Par value is $1. What is the total credit to Common Stock and APIC combined?
questions.explanation: Cash received = 1,000 × $25 = $25,000. APIC—Stock Options reclassified = 1,000 × $10 = $10,000. Total credited to Common Stock ($1,000 at par) and APIC ($34,000) = $35,000.
questions.tip: Exercise: Cash + APIC reclassified = total credits to stock accounts.

questions.question: Restricted stock granted to employees is measured at:

options.A: Zero, since no cash is exchanged
options.B: The stock's intrinsic value at grant date
options.C: The stock's fair value at grant date
options.D: The stock's fair value at vesting date

questions.explanation: Restricted stock is measured at the fair value of the stock at the grant date. Since restricted stock is actual shares (not options), the fair value equals the stock price on the grant date.
questions.tip: Restricted stock fair value = stock price at grant date.

questions.question: A key difference between restricted stock and restricted stock units (RSUs) is:

options.B: Restricted stock shareholders receive dividends during the vesting period; RSU holders typically do not
options.C: RSUs must be expensed over a longer period
options.D: Restricted stock is measured at intrinsic value while RSUs are measured at fair value

questions.explanation: Restricted stock grants actual shares at the grant date, so recipients typically receive dividends during vesting. RSU holders receive shares (or cash) only upon vesting and typically do not receive dividends until then.
questions.tip: Restricted stock = actual shares (dividends). RSUs = promise of shares (no dividends until vesting).

questions.question: Stock options with a performance condition (e.g., achieving target EPS) are accounted for by:

options.A: Recognizing expense only if performance target is probable of being achieved
options.B: Always recognizing expense regardless of probability
options.C: Reducing the fair value of the option by the probability of achieving the target
options.D: Delaying all expense recognition until the performance period ends

questions.explanation: For performance conditions, compensation expense is recognized only if it is probable the condition will be achieved. The probability assessment is updated each period, with cumulative adjustments to expense.
questions.tip: Performance conditions: recognize expense if probable of achievement.

questions.question: Stock options with a market condition (e.g., stock price must reach $50) are accounted for by:

options.A: Recognizing expense only if the market condition is achieved
options.B: Incorporating the market condition into the grant-date fair value and recognizing expense regardless of outcome
options.C: Adjusting expense each period based on likelihood of achieving the market condition
options.D: Using intrinsic value instead of fair value

questions.explanation: Market conditions are incorporated into the grant-date fair value using option pricing models. Compensation expense is recognized regardless of whether the market condition is ultimately achieved (no true-up).
questions.tip: Market conditions: baked into fair value, expense recognized regardless of outcome.

questions.question: On January 1, Year 1, XYZ Corp granted 9,000 stock options with a fair value of $12 per option. The options vest in three tranches: 3,000 at end of Year 1, 3,000 at end of Year 2, and 3,000 at end of Year 3. Using the accelerated method, what is Year 1 compensation expense?
questions.explanation: Tranche 1 (vests in 1 year): 3,000 × $12 = $36,000 in Year 1. Tranche 2 (vests in 2 years): 3,000 × $12 ÷ 2 = $18,000 in Year 1. Tranche 3 (vests in 3 years): 3,000 × $12 ÷ 3 = $12,000 in Year 1. Total Year 1 = $66,000.
questions.tip: Graded vesting (accelerated): treat each tranche as separate award.

questions.question: When a company modifies employee stock options to increase their fair value, the incremental compensation cost is:

options.B: Recognized over the remaining vesting period
options.C: Not recognized; original fair value is maintained
options.D: Recognized over the original vesting period

questions.explanation: When stock options are modified, the incremental fair value (new fair value minus old fair value at modification date) is recognized over the remaining vesting period. The original compensation cost continues to be recognized.
questions.tip: Modification: incremental value over remaining vesting period.

questions.question: During the vesting period, a company records a deferred tax asset related to stock compensation based on:

options.B: The intrinsic value of the options
options.C: The tax deduction that will be received at exercise
options.D: Zero, since stock compensation creates a permanent difference

questions.explanation: A deferred tax asset is recorded based on cumulative book compensation expense multiplied by the tax rate. This creates a temporary difference because the tax deduction occurs at exercise (based on intrinsic value) rather than over the vesting period.
questions.tip: DTA during vesting = cumulative book expense × tax rate.

questions.question: Cash-settled stock appreciation rights (SARs) are classified as:

options.A: Equity awards measured at grant-date fair value
options.C: Equity awards with no expense recognition

questions.explanation: Cash-settled SARs are classified as liability awards because they will be settled in cash. As liability awards, they are remeasured at fair value each reporting period until settlement, with changes in expense.
questions.tip: Cash-settled = liability = remeasure each period.

questions.question: An employee stock purchase plan (ESPP) is noncompensatory if it meets certain criteria, including a purchase discount of no more than:
questions.explanation: An ESPP is noncompensatory (no compensation expense) if: (1) it is available to substantially all employees, (2) the discount is 5% or less, and (3) the plan has no option features. A discount over 5% makes the plan compensatory.
questions.tip: ESPP noncompensatory: ≤5% discount, available to all, no option features.

questions.question: Under current GAAP, stock-based compensation awards to nonemployees are:

options.A: Measured at the fair value of goods/services received
options.B: Accounted for the same as employee awards (grant-date fair value)

questions.explanation: After ASU 2018-07, nonemployee share-based payments are accounted for the same as employee awards—measured at grant-date fair value and recognized over the vesting/service period.
questions.tip: Post-2018: nonemployee awards = same as employee awards.

questions.question: When vested employee stock options expire unexercised, the company should:

options.A: Reverse the previously recognized compensation expense
options.B: Recognize a gain in the income statement
options.C: Make no adjustment; the APIC remains in equity
options.D: Transfer the amount from APIC to retained earnings

questions.explanation: When vested options expire unexercised, no adjustment is made. The amount in APIC—Stock Options remains in equity. The compensation was earned by the employee through service, regardless of whether they exercised.
questions.tip: Expired vested options: no reversal, APIC stays put.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a typical input to the Black-Scholes option pricing model?
questions.explanation: Black-Scholes inputs include: current stock price, exercise price, expected term, risk-free rate, expected volatility, and expected dividends. The company's debt-to-equity ratio is not a direct input.
questions.tip: Black-Scholes inputs: stock price, strike, term, rate, volatility, dividends.

questions.question: A service condition for stock options (e.g., must remain employed for 3 years) affects:

options.A: The fair value of the award
options.B: The period over which expense is recognized
options.C: Whether the award is classified as equity or liability

questions.explanation: Service conditions affect the requisite service period (vesting period) over which compensation expense is recognized. They do not affect the grant-date fair value calculation.
questions.tip: Service conditions = when to expense (not fair value).
